titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nicolas Nabokov Papers
titlestmt.author: by Karen Spicher

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:26

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

langmaterial.language: In French, Russian, English, and German.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: Series I. Correspondence, 1928-1980. II. Music and Writings, 1927-1999.

bioghist.head: Nicolas Nabokov (1903-1978)
bioghist.p: American composer of Russian birth; cousin of Russian-American author Vladimir Nabokov, and husband of photographer Dominique Nabokov.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Nicolas Nabokov Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Dominique Nabokov on the Edith and Richard French Fund and the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2004.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Nicolas Nabokov Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat Mss 618 and Uncat Mss 716. In 2014, the collection received a baseline level of processing, including partial rehousing and minimal organization. The collection was reclassed under one call number, materials were organized into series, and containers were renumbered in a single sequence. Most folder titles were based on information provided by the creator or vendor, while some were assigned by Library staff. Folder titles were not verified against contents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, music, and writings, most 1928-1930s or 1960s-1970s, with some later correspondence and notes of Dominque Nabokov. Most correspondence is with musicians, including Pierre Boulez, Paul Collaer, Roger Désormière, Wilhelm Furtwängler, Aram Khachaturian, Lina Prokofiev, Igor Markevitch, Igor Stravinsky, and Virgil Thomson. Other correspondents include Vladimir Nabokov and members of the Nabokov family, 1932-1977. Music and writings include Ode: Méditation sur la majesté de Dieu, a ballet-oratorio, autograph manuscript full score and vocal score, 1927 and undated, and printed vocal scores (Editions Maurice Senart, c1928); libretti, correspondence, and printed materials relating to other ballets, oratorios, and operas, 1920s-1990s; a typescript draft of Bagázh: memoirs of a Russian cosmopolitan (New York: Atheneum, 1975), undated; and drafts of writings about Igor Stravinsky, 1960s-1970s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent or subject, followed by unsorted

did.unittitle: Hofmannsthal, Raimund von, and Hofmannsthal, Elizabeth von
Morris, Brewster H., and Morris, Helen
Nabokov, Vladimir; Nabokova, Vera; and Nabokov, Dmitri
New York City Ballet, and Cage, Betty
Rothschild, Philippe, baron de, and Rothschild, Pauline, baroness de
Stravinsky festival (Paris and Berlin, 1980) (notes and printed material)
Bagázh: Memoirs of a Russian Cosmopolitan (memoir)
Don Quixote (ballet; libretto by Nabokov and George Balanchine)
Synopsis and libretto (manuscript and typescript), and photographs
"The Gracious Master" (biography of Igor Stravinsky). Typescript, with revisions
Job (oratorio; libretto by Jacques Maritain). Libretto fragments, correspondence, and printed material
The Last Flower (ballet; after James Thurber). Manuscript music fragment and correspondence
Love's Labour's Lost (opera; libretto by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman, after William Shakespeare)
Related writings by Nabokov and Kallmann, reviews, and other printed material
The Nutcracker (film scenario by Nabokov and George Balanchine, after E. T. A. Hoffmann)
Ode: Méditation sur la majesté de Dieu (ballet-oratorio; libretto by Roger Désormière, after Mikhail Vasilʹevich Lomonosov)
Vocal score (printed, Editions Maurice Senart). Photocopy
Paul et Virginie (opera; libretto by Jean Cocteau and Raymond Radiguet). Libretto, typescript photocopy
Der Tod des Grigorij Rasputin (opera; libretto by Nabokov and Stephen Spender)
Libretto in English, by Spender (autograph manuscript and typescript)
Libretto and set design, in English, Act I (typescript carbon)
"A Partisan Chronicle" (about Igor Stravinsky). Typescript and autograph manuscript
"The Peasant Marriage" (notes for lecture about Les noces , by Igor Stravinsky,). Typescript photocopy, with revisions
Variations on a Theme by Tchaikovsky (cello and orchestra). Printed program from performance
